content.content:
## What ‚Äúgood‚Äù sounds like on a call

- You speak in **dollars first**, then explain the physics only as needed.
- You can translate **any** technical detail into: **cost**, **risk**, or **comfort**.
- You ask 5‚Äì7 discovery questions, then recommend **quick wins first**.

**One-liner:** ‚ÄúWe reduce energy spend and operational headaches ‚Äî usually with optimization before replacement.‚Äù

sections.title: Industry Lingo & Terminology
sections.subtitle: Say it like the trades do (without sounding fake)

content.content: Use lingo to **build trust**, not to flex. If you don‚Äôt know a term, ask: ‚ÄúWhen you say ___, do you mean ___?‚Äù

items.title: HVAC equipment basics (RTU, AHU, VAV, DOAS)

content.content:
- **RTU**: Rooftop Unit (packaged HVAC on the roof).
- **AHU**: Air Handling Unit (moves/conditions air; often in a mechanical room).
- **VAV**: Variable Air Volume (boxes modulate airflow to zones).
- **DOAS**: Dedicated Outdoor Air System (handles ventilation separately).

**Example:** ‚ÄúIf you have VAV, we‚Äôll look for reheat and scheduling ‚Äî that‚Äôs where the money usually is.‚Äù

- **DDC**: Direct Digital Control (modern controls).
- **BAS/BMS**: Building Automation/System (central controls).
- **Economizer**: Uses outdoor air for ‚Äúfree cooling‚Äù when conditions allow.
- **Reset**: Adjust setpoints based on conditions (CHW reset, SAT reset, static pressure reset).

**Example:** ‚ÄúBefore we replace equipment, we usually unlock 10‚Äì25% just with schedules + resets.‚Äù

- **VFD**: Variable Frequency Drive (slows motors; huge savings on fans/pumps).
- **ECM**: Efficient motor type (common in newer fans).
- **Fan wall**: Array of smaller fans replacing one big fan.

**Example:** ‚ÄúIf that supply fan is constant-speed, a VFD + controls is often a fast payback.‚Äù

- **kW/ton**: Power per ton of cooling (lower = better).
- **COP**: Coefficient of performance (output/input).
- **EER/SEER**: Cooling efficiency ratings (unit-dependent).
- **IPLV**: Part-load efficiency (often more important than full-load).

**Example:** ‚ÄúMost systems live at part load ‚Äî we care more about IPLV than the brochure number.‚Äù

content.caption: Sales-friendly unit cheat sheet

content.content:
## kW vs kWh (the one you must nail)

- **kW** is the **speedometer**.
- **kWh** is the **odometer**.

Why it matters: many commercial bills charge both **energy ($/kWh)** *and* **demand ($/kW)**.

## What is a therm?

- **1 therm = 100,000 BTU**.
- If gas is **$1.50/therm**, then burning 10,000 therms/year costs **$15,000/year** (before demand/fixed charges).

**Sales angle:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll reduce therms by cutting unnecessary heating (schedules, reheat, heat recovery) before we talk about replacing boilers.‚Äù

sections.title: CFM Cost Analysis
sections.subtitle: How expensive is 1 CFM when it‚Äôs heated/cooled?

content.quote: Rule of thumb: in many commercial buildings, 1 CFM of conditioned air can be worth roughly $15‚Äì$25 per CFM per year. Treat this as a fast, directional sizing tool ‚Äî climate, hours, and % outdoor air can swing it a lot.

content.content:
## Why CFM becomes dollars

Airflow costs money because you pay to:

- **Move it** (fan kWh)
- **Cool it** (compressor/chiller kWh)
- **Heat it** (therms or kWh)
- **Dehumidify it** (often hidden but huge)

**Sales move:** If you find ‚Äútoo much air‚Äù (excess OA, stuck dampers, constant volume, poor controls), you often found a big check.

content.explanation: Use this only to explain the drivers. For fast selling, use the $/CFM-year heuristic with clear caveats.

rows: 50,000 CFM √ó $18 ‚âà $900k/year airflow-related energy opportunity (not all recoverable).
200,000 CFM √ó $14 ‚âà $2.8M/year directional; focus on controls + infiltration.
80,000 CFM √ó $28 ‚âà $2.24M/year directional; heat recovery is often key.
10,000 CFM √ó $30 ‚âà $300k/year directional; DCKV can be a hammer.
60,000 CFM √ó $20 ‚âà $1.2M/year directional; focus on containment + free cooling.

sections.title: Free Cooling & Free Heating
sections.subtitle: Sell ‚Äúusing what you already have‚Äù before buying equipment

content.content:
- Dampers stuck / disabled
- Outdoor air not used when it‚Äôs cool outside
- Mechanical cooling runs when it doesn‚Äôt need to

- Economizer enabled and tested
- Outdoor air used during favorable conditions
- Compressor/chiller runtime reduced

- Exhaust air dumped outside
- Boilers fire while you‚Äôre throwing heat away
- Reheat runs even when not needed

- Heat recovery (ERV/HRV/heat wheel/runaround) captures waste heat
- Controls prioritize recovered heat
- Heating energy reduced; comfort often improves

## How to sell it (simple)

- **Pitch:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll use outdoor air and recovered heat before we buy new machines.‚Äù
- **Proof:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll trend temperatures + damper positions + runtime and show the delta.‚Äù
- **Expectation setting:** Savings depend on climate, schedules, and sequences.

sections.title: Reading Utility Bills
sections.subtitle: Extract the money story fast

content.content:
## The 3-minute method

1) Find **total $** and **total kWh** (energy story)
2) Find **peak kW** and **$/kW** (demand story)
3) Note **TOU periods** (when the pain happens)
4) Ask about **operating hours** (scheduling opportunity)

**Key insight:** Two buildings with the same kWh can have wildly different bills because of **demand charges**.

rows: Reduce runtime and kWh (LEDs, VFDs, controls, efficiency).
Peak shaving, staging, setpoints, pre-cool, batteries (where applicable).
Shift load, reduce peak-period usage, schedule intelligently.
Usually not controllable; focus on big levers above.

## Example (simple)

- Project cost: **$100,000**

content.content:
- Typical big loads: HVAC + plug loads + lighting
- Common wins: schedules, VFDs, controls tuning, LEDs
- Sales angle: comfort complaints + predictable savings

- Big loads: lighting + HVAC + (sometimes) refrigeration
- Common wins: LEDs + controls, RTU controls, door/infiltration management
- Sales angle: fast payback + maintenance reduction

- Big loads: process + compressed air + motors

sections.title: Site Walk Basics
sections.subtitle: What to look for, fast

items: **Take photos** of nameplates + controls (age, refrigerant, kW/HP, efficiency ratings).
**Find schedules**: what runs when no one‚Äôs there?
**Look for constant-speed** fans/pumps that should be variable.
**Look for outside air issues**: stuck dampers, wide-open OA, broken economizers.
**Ask about comfort calls**: hot/cold, humidity, odors, noise.
**Request docs**: 12 months bills, equipment list, setpoints, sequences (if BAS).

content.content:
## Red flags (usually money)

- Equipment running **24/7** without a reason
- Old pneumatic or poorly tuned controls
- Simultaneous heating + cooling (reheat) in mild weather
- Dirty coils/filters, obvious maintenance gaps
- Oversized equipment short-cycling

sections.title: Simple Savings Calculations
sections.subtitle: Quick math to size savings on a call

content.explanation: If you can estimate kW reduction and hours, you can estimate kWh savings.
Demand charges can dominate the bill in many commercial accounts.

content.content:
## Example

If you reduce peak demand by **100 kW** and demand is **$15/kW-month**:

- Annual demand savings ‚âà 100 √ó 15 √ó 12 = **$18,000/year**

If you reduce average load by **30 kW** over **8,760 hours/year**:

- kWh savings ‚âà 30 √ó 8,760 = **262,800 kWh/year**
- At **$0.15/kWh**, energy savings ‚âà **$39,420/year**

Total directional savings ‚âà **$57,420/year**

sections.title: Understanding System Integration
sections.subtitle: Stacking savings without double-counting

content.content:
## The key idea

Measures interact.

- LEDs reduce lighting kWh **and** reduce cooling load (less heat).
- Better schedules reduce kWh **and** reduce peak kW.
- Controls often make equipment upgrades perform as promised.

**Sales move:** ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll sequence projects so savings stack and performance is verifiable.‚Äù

sections.title: Common Misconceptions
sections.subtitle: Quick reality checks that keep deals alive

content.content:
- ‚ÄúWe need to replace everything.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúOur rates are low, so savings will be small.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúNew equipment always fixes comfort.‚Äù

- Optimization often delivers 10‚Äì30% before replacement.
- Demand charges + runtime waste can be large even with low $/kWh.
- Comfort problems are often controls + airflow + zoning issues.

sections.title: Summary of Everything
sections.subtitle: Your ‚Äúwhat to do next‚Äù map

content.content:
## If you remember nothing else

1) Lead with **annual $** + **risk reduction**.
2) Know the units: **kW, kWh, therm, CFM**.
3) Start with **quick wins** (schedules, controls, VFDs, LEDs, economizers).
4) Use bills to tell the story: **$/kWh** and **$/kW**.
5) Ask discovery questions and align to the stakeholder‚Äôs metric.
